div.p: This element belongs conceptually within WRITING PRODUCTION . It details the pre-publication or unpublished history of a text: where it was kept, how and if it circulated before and after its printing. This element incorporates a statement or discussion; note that it refers to the circulation of the manuscript and not the published text, and covers matters like ownership, damage, loss and recovery. It has no mandatory or optional sub-elements or attributes.

div.codeblock: <PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY><PARCHIVALLOCATION>Lucy Cary's manuscript remained in the convent archives and is now Lille MS 20H9.</PARCHIVALLOCATION></PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY>

<PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY>The manuscripts of Ann Grant's memoirs are in two large vellum-bound volumes. Family history states that these were originally passed down to Annie, AG's second daughter.</PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY>

<PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY>Elizabeth Cellier's account of her arrest was allegedly written at first in a "scrambling ugly hand." She had a fair copy made, got it printed, and sold it from her house.</PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY>

div.p: If the manuscript has come to rest at an archival location, and that is all we know, record the information in ARCHIVALLOCATION. However, you may overlap tags where necessary: see example above.
Information about the circulation of published texts should use the PCIRCULATION element, use PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY if an unprinted work had readers remarkable for their numbers or identity.
